**INSTITUTION ENDOCRINE CONSULTATION PATIENT NAME: **NAME[AAA, BBB M] ACCOUNT #: **ID-NUM **ROOM ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY M ZZZ] CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[WWW XXX], M.D. ADMISSION DATE: **DATE[Jul 03 2007] DATE OF CONSULTATION: REASON FOR CONSULT: New onset diabetes mellitus. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mr. **NAME[AAA] is a **AGE[in 40s]-year-old, white male with systemic lupus erythematosus and lupus nephritis who presented to **INSTITUTION with polydipsia, polyuria and blood glucose in the 900s after being started on prednisone for the last month for lupus flare. Anion gap was 17, but there were no urine ketones, but he was admitted to the MICU for treatment of DKA. Endocrine was consulted for new onset diabetes, possibly prednisone induced. About a month ago, the patient had laboratory work drawn by Dr. **NAME[TTT] who is his rheumatologist and he also had a funny taste in the back of his mouth which is what he gets with his lupus flares. He had a 24 hour urine done which showed 10 grams of protein, so his CellCept was increased from 500 to 1500 b.i.d. and he was started on prednisone 16 mg once a day with plans to taper after one month of treatment. Over the last few weeks, the patient had been drinking four to five gallons of fluid a day and also had polyuria where he would get up to urinate every 15 to 30 minutes. He also had orthostatic dizziness. No nausea, vomiting, no shortness of breath, chest pain, vision changes or headache. On admission, the patient was treated with IV fluids and an insulin drip and his anion gap closed in six hours. Potassium went from 6.1 to 4.7, creatinine from 2.0 to 1.5 which is his baseline. There are no ketones present in the urine. Urine glucose was 1000 and protein was 30. Blood glucose went from 900 to 400. The patient's polydipsia and polyuria have improved. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: No fevers or chills. No leg edema. No diarrhea or constipation. No burning on urination. Decreased appetite, but this is improving. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1) Systemic lupus erythematosus diagnosed in 2002, being followed by Dr. **NAME[TTT]. Manifestations include arthritis, renal, CNS and cutaneous. The patient is also anticardiolipin antibody positive. 2) Hyperlipidemia. 3) Hypertension. 4) Tumor cerebri in remission. SOCIAL HISTORY: Positive for tobacco and marijuana. No alcohol or IV drugs. FAMILY HISTORY: Grandmother with diabetes. ALLERGIES: NONE KNOWN. HOME MEDICATIONS: 1) CellCept 1500 mg p.o. b.i.d. 2) Prednisone 60 mg p.o. daily. 3) Diovan 160 mg p.o. daily. 4) Atenolol 25 mg p.o. daily. 5) Coumadin 5 mg p.o. daily. 6) Lasix. INPATIENT MEDICATIONS include home medications except for Lasix which has been held. Also he is on Protonix 40 mg p.o. b.i.d., insulin drip and normal saline IV fluids at 100 cc per hour. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VITALS: Temperature 36.1, blood pressure 154/73, pulse 79, respirations 20, O2 saturations 94% on room air. Weight is 122 kg. GENERAL: No apparent distress, alert and oriented times three. HEENT: No cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharynx clear. CARDIOVASCULAR: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. PULMONARY: Clear to auscultation. No wheezing, rales or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, obese, nontender, nondistended, bowel sounds present. EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. SKIN: No malar rash or any other lesions. NEUROLOGIC: Pupils equal and reactive. Extraocular movements intact. Nonfocal. LABORATORY DATA: Potassium was 6.1, now 5.2, sodium was 123, corrected for glucose was 128, now it is 132. Bicarb was 20 and now is 16, creatinine was 2.0, now is 1.5. Blood glucose was 900, now is 400. Anion gap was 17 and is now 9.0. White count is 11.3. Hemoglobin is 15.7. Urine has no ketones, glucose is 1000, leukocyte esterase and nitrates are absent, protein is 30. 24-hour urine **DATE[May 29] showed 10.2 grams of protein. Chest x-ray shows no acute process. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Mr. **NAME[AAA] is a **AGE[in 40s]-year-old, white male with SLE, a lupus nephritis on prednisone for the last month, presenting with hyperosmolar hyperglycemia. The absence of ketones in a relatively small, although increased anion gap, and lack of any other symptoms besides polyuria, makes DKA an unlikely diagnosis. This patient has steroid-induced diabetes mellitus at the very least which may or may not resolve after the prednisone is discontinued. As the patient has lupus nephritis and renal insufficiency at baseline, oral hypoglycemic options are limited. The best option at this point would be to start the patient on subcu insulin. 1) Check hemoglobin A1c. 2) The patient is not currently on a statin despite having an elevated cholesterol. Check LFTs and consider starting Vytoran. 3) Blood pressure goal in diabetics is 130/80. The patient currently is not meeting this goal and his blood pressure medications will need to be adjusted accordingly. 4) Nutrition and diabetic education consult. 5) Start Lantus 25 units subcu q.h.s. (bedtime) and Humalog 8 units with meals three times a day. Humalog sliding scale insulin low dose. 6) Will discuss with attending.
